interlinear-text.item: Mahmudov Handzharbek born in 1949 Vrang village recorded in 1965

phrase.item: There was [and] there wasn't. There was one King.
He had two wives.
One of them was despised, the other beloved.
One day, the wife he despised bore a son, and the wife he loved bore two sons.
And so one day the father calls to his sons and says: "Whoever acquires a fortune, he will be my favorite."
One day, they prepare provisions for the road. ‎‎The favored sons get bread, meat and butter prepared for them, and the despised one gets only scraps.
The favored sons ride on horseback, and the hated one - on foot with a bag on his back.
As they ride up the road, they see: one stone has written on it, "You'll go and you'll return", and another has written on it, "You'll go and you won't return".
The favored sons head down the road that says, "You'll go and you'll return".
And the despised one goes down the road where it says, "You'll go and you won't return."
So he's walking, [and] suddenly he meets an old man, who had forty treasure-troves.
He kept forty keys to them in forty pairs of trousers. The young boy steals the keys from the old man, takes the treasure, [and] leaves.
He comes to a certain place, piles up his riches, and goes off to look for his brothers.
He comes to another place, [and] sees his brothers are scorching sheep heads.
Their hair had wrapped itself around their necks.
He puts their heads in order, and then takes them to the place where his fortune is hidden.
When they arrive, he pulls out clothes for them, [and] says: "Stand watch tonight, so that no one makes off with our fortune."
The brothers remain to stand guard.
At nightfall they stick a sword [into the ground] in front of the tent opening.
As soon as their brother falls asleep, they yell: "Uh oh, someone made off with your fortune!"
He jumps up,
and one of those brothers strikes him hard in the legs with the sword, and he becomes lame, can't even make a step.
And the two brothers ride off with his fortune.
Lame, he barely crawls, makes it to a tree.
There he meets a blind old man.
The old man suggests to him: "You'll be my eyes, and I'll be your legs!"
And he heaves him up on his back.
They come to a spring, and there are ever so many different birds by this spring.
They ask a crow: "How can a lame man and a blind man get healed?"
The crow replies: "The lame man must dunk his legs thrice into this spring,
and the blind man must wash his eyes with water from it."
Having heard this, the lame lad dunks his legs thrice into it, and his legs get healed.
And the blind man washes his eyes three times with that water, and he gains sight.
Then they continued on, that despised lad and the old man.
The old man went off home, and that young man back to his house.
He arrives, and the brothers say: "We were the ones who acquired the fortune!"
And the brother says: "No, [it was] I."
The two favored sons disagree: "We brought this!"
Then the despised son says: "Go on then, show me the keys from the forty treasure-troves!"
They say: "We won't show you."
They go to the father.
The despised son shows his father the keys from the forty treasure-troves.
The father believes [him]: "Yes, my unloved son acquired this fortune." After that, he becomes his father's favorite, and those other two - despised.
And a while later, he chases them from the house for good.
